results.title: The Birdcage
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation and Mike Nichols
results.brief_description: Armand (Robin Williams) and Albert (Nathan Lane) have created their own piece of serenity with their successful nightclub, “The Birdcage”. Armand takes care of the management and Albert performs nightly as the wonderful female impersonator, Starina. Their world is thrown into disarray when Armand’s son announces he is engaged to a conservative Senator’s daughter who is eager to meet their future son in laws parents. It will take all of Albert’s stage experience to convince the future in laws they are a ‘normal’ family. This reworking of the classic French farce ‘La Cage aux Folles’ will delight viewers with it sparkling humour and great performances by Robin Williams, Nathan Lane, Hank Azaria, Gene Hackman, Dianne Wiest, Dan Futterman and Calista Flockhart.

results.title: The Bird with the crystal plumage = L'Uccello dalle piume di cristallo
results.creator_credit: Glazier, Speda Spettacoli, CCC Filmkunst, Salvatore Argento and Dario Argento
results.brief_description: An American writer (Tony Musante) working in Italy witnesses an attempted murder when passing an art gallery one night. The attacker escapes making the writer the key witness and potentially, the next victim. Loosely based on a novel by Brian Edgar Wallace, Argento’s first feature helped established the Italian filmmakers reputation as the master of the Gaillo genre (Giallo meaning yellow, the colour of the cheap and lurid horror/thriller paperback novels sold in Italy). ‘The bird with the crystal plumage’s‘ stylish and violent set pieces (enhanced by Vitorrio Storaro’s fluid cinematography and Ennio Morricone’s unnerving score) had Argento dubbed in his home country as the Italian Hitchcock. The comparisons don’t end there however, as both directors also share a taste for sly black humour which Argento displays through the array of oddball characters that populate the film, including a demented artist who eats cats and a pimp with a neurotic streak. Cast also includes Suzy Kendall, Enrico Maria Salerno, Eva Renzi, Reggie Nalder and Mario Adorf. See also ‘Deep red’ (1975), ‘Suspiria’ (1977) and ‘Trauma’ (1993).

results.title: The Bird who is a clown
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Walker
results.brief_description: Introduces the island Daphne Major of the Galapagos Islands which is a small island and nesting ground for hundrreds of Blue-footed Booby birds. Emphasises the mating and upbringing of the young in order to illustrate the development of the Booby and to reveal its behaviour patterns. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Bird fancier = L'Homme aux oiseaux
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover, Bernard Devlin and Jean Palardy
results.brief_description: Staged in old Quebec City, this film is about a rebel against the time-clock, whose hobby was snaring birds but whose dream was to escape the bonds of domesticity. A kindly satire of the dreamer in every man, the film is also a memorable portrait of Quebec, the “Grande Dame” of Canadian cities. With English subtitles. Cast includes Maurice Beaupre, Rene Constantineau, Camille Fournier, Roger Lebel, Annette Leclerc. Written by Roger Lemelin. Photography by Grant McLean. Edited by Douglas Tunstell. Music by Maurice Blackburn. Sound by Joseph Champagne.

results.title: The Biosphere
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells, Peter Katadotis, Colin Low and William Pettigrew
results.brief_description: The McKenzie and Amazon Valleys are 10,000 kilometres distant from one another and are certainly distinct ecologically. Yet in a subtle sense they are collaborating elements within the biosphere - the Earth’s thin layer of living matter. This film examines two of the myriad river ecosystems and shows how they are linked within the biosphere.

results.title: The biology of behavior
results.creator_credit: Coastline Community College, David Stone, Steven Talley and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Humans are quick thinking, quick acting animals. This ability to react is controlled by the nervous system, which in turn is controlled by a complex system of neurotransmitters in the brain. This program examines the operation of these neurotransmitters, their effect on individual personality and what happens when these networks break down due to neurotransmitter diseases, in particular, Parkinson’s Disease.

results.title: The Biological control of insects [Excerpt]
results.brief_description: Shows a number of insect pests close-up in the laboratory. Outlines the success with which they have been controlled by their natural enemies and by the use of virus diseases. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: The Biological control of insects
results.brief_description: Shows some aspects of the entomologist’s work in his attempts to control insect pests by the use of their natural enemies. In telling the story of biological control the following pests are shown in cloe-up: cottony cushion scale, cabbage moth, green vegetable bug, cabbage white butterfly, vegetable weevil and Queensland fruit fly. Their natural enemies include predators, parasites and diseases.

results.title: The Biography of the motion picture camera
results.creator_credit: Les Films du Compas and Roger Leenhardt
results.brief_description: The story of the motion picture camera, carries further the history of the antecedents of cinema, showing how the development of the cinema arose out of scientists desire to analyse movement, in order to study the movements of animals and birds. The first man to undertake a scientific study of movement was Marey, a french physician; his experiments were extended by Edward Muybridge, a San Francisco photographer, who settled a trans-Atlantic argument about the way a horse gallops by using a battery of 24 cameras to photograph its movements. The problem then remained of creating one camera capable of doing the job of these 24. Marey, among others, achieved this by inventing the chronophotograph; Edison in America made a further advance by introducing celluloid film in place of photographic plates. Edison also invented a projector, which allowed only one person to view the film; it was Louis Lumiere in France who invented the first successful commercial projector which enabled him to show motion picture films to a fairly large audience. The Lumiere brothers began to make films about every-day events which at the time proved sensational.
